editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Love's mistress: or, the Queen's masque.
As it was three times presented before their two excellent majesties, within the space of eight days; in the presence of sundry foreign ambassadors.
Publicly acted by the Queens comedians, at the phoenix in Drury-lane.
London, printed by Robert Raworth, for John crouch; and are to be sold by jasper Emery, at the sign of the eagle and child, in Paul's churchyard. 1636.

sp.p: But father, no tongue shall her joys express.

lg.l: But since you never shall behold his face,

Is't possible, by deeds impossible
To attain the crown of immortality:
It cannot be; the mocking Phoebus leaves us,

lg.l: I'll gather rods of roses, if you mock 〈◊〉
With your anon-forsooth.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Anon-forsooth.

lg.l: Shall I be still thus vexed? still when my blood
Boils in the fire of anger, than this ape
With purpose frets me. — boy.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Anon-forsooth.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Will Juno come, or Ceres? ◊〉

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Juno lay lolling in my uncle's lap.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Which uncle?

lg.l: Uncle 〈◊〉: I laughed outright
To see how (Want on-like) with both her 〈◊〉
She clung about his neck; gave him ten kisses,
Toyed with his locks, looked babies in his eyes,
And 〈◊〉 she would not watch him when he went
Amongst his wenches, if he'd turn● away
His saucy page, the smooth-faced 〈◊〉;
The boy by chance upon her fan had spilt
A cup of nectar; o how Juno swore:
I told my aunt I'd give her a new 〈◊〉,
to let Jove's page be Cupid's servingman.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: What's this to Venus' message, what said 〈◊〉?

lg.l: I asked her when she'd come, and in good sooth,
She answered nothing but anon-forsooth.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: And where was Ceres, what did she reply?

lg.l: Ceres was binding garlands for God pan,
Of blew-●●●●ies, and yellow pi●●●beds
That grew amongst the wheat, with which she crowned
His forked brows, and wooed him with his horn
To rouse the skipping satyrs, to go hunt
A herd of swine that rooted up her come:
I asked her wh●● she'd come, and in good sooth
She sent me packing with anon forsooth.
I sent for pan, and for Apollo too,
What news from them?

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.p: They said they would be here immediately.

sp.speaker: Apo.
sp.p: Why in such haste hath Venus sent for us?

lg.l: I sent for Juno, and for Ceres too,
But they'll not come.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Well, what's the news with you?

lg.l: Have you not heard how Venus is contemned?
Her temples gazed at, but not trodded upon,
Her stately hangings, and her pillows torn;
Those rosy garlands that her ●●●●●es crowned,
Are withered, or else trampled on the ground;
Those troops that flocked to Paphos to adore me,
Shun Paphos now, and scornfully abhor me.
That's strange, for all 〈◊〉 up to 〈◊〉 in love ▪
Boys without beards get boys, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉,

sp.speaker: Ven.

A sweet kiss;
And Phoebus shall have one, 〈◊〉 another,

Which Psyche in her great pride throws o 〈◊〉:

of roses, mixed with 〈◊〉 hair;

sp.p: I will forsooth.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Nay do not mock me, wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Yes indeed, indeed I will forsooth.

lg.l: Sweet lad 〈◊〉 then ▪
Apollo, pan, revenge poor Venus' 〈◊〉,
Whilst i 〈◊〉 my silver coloured team,
To wanton on the bosom of yon stream.
Now she hath called me down unto the earth,
I'll try what pastimes dwell amongst the swains.
And with my satires I will have some sport
Here in the 〈◊〉 vaslyes.
Shall Psyche's beauteous eyes gaze on base love?
No, let my mother storm, and 〈◊〉 and lower,
She shall be none but Cupid's paramour:
Ho Zephirus, — how now thou puffing slave,
Art thou grown proud, thou swellest so? Gentle wind,
Clap on thy smoothest feathers, 〈◊〉 wings,
And mount thee to the top of yonder rock,
There shalt thou find anon, a forlorn 〈◊〉,
Convey her gently down into the vale
That borders on my bower; 〈◊〉 this performed,
And I will clothe thee in a grass-green robe,

I'll play the thief in 〈◊〉 treasury,
To 〈◊〉 all eyes in love with Zephirus;
〈◊〉 hence, do this, and henceforth be thou King

div.stage: Enter Admetus, Menetius, Zelotis, Astioche, Petrea, Psiche.

lg.l: Behold the foot of that unhappy rock,
Upon whose frozen top, by Phoebus' 〈◊〉,
Thou must abide thy most sinister hap.

sp.speaker: Astio.
sp.p: Dear sister 〈◊〉.

lg.l: Peace Astioche,
Petrea, father: you should all have mourned
When the mad spirits of the multitude
Kneeled down, and called me 〈◊〉, then have wept,
When Cytharea's altars were left bare ▪
And I was called a goddess; when these tears,
Whose 〈◊〉 makes my funeral lights burn dim,
Might have quenched Venus' wrath; but leave me now
To fight with death, or 〈◊〉 worse misery.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.p: But lurks that serpent in this 〈◊〉 rock?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: So said Apollo.

lg.l: Then Menetius,
We will conduct fair Psiche to the cave,
And rip the monsters entrails with our swords.
Forbear all force, I will ascend alone ▪
Phoebus will be displeased; alone said he,
Distressed Psyche shall climb up yond hill.
The way is dangerous, thou wilt lose thyself
Without a guide.
If thus I talk to them, — who fills this wine,
And tempts my eye with it? as who should say,
Drink Psyche.

sp.speaker: Eccho.
sp.p: Drink Psyche. 2. Drink Psyche. 3. Drink Psyche,

lg.l: I'll taste no drop of this enchanted wine:
Fain from this magic 〈◊〉 would I rise,
Y● dare not; o let Psyche see your eyes,
Or rid me hence, and set my fears in peace.

sp.speaker: Ecch.
sp.p: Peace. 2. Peace. 3. Peace.

lg.l: How lovely is my Psyche; earth's too base
To be possessed of her celestial form:
My mother hates her; for the gods I fear
Would banish her from earth, my love being there;
And therefore shall she live in Cupid's bower,
For she 〈◊〉 to be loves paramour:
O how my fair eyes wound me; by this kiss,
And this white hand.
O me! what voice is this
I 〈◊〉? besides, soft fingers, and a ring.
Long white fingers; soft white hand,
Ring and all at thy command.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: Is this my husband then?

lg.l: Ho Zephirus,
Remove hence these ambrosian dishes straight.
My father much mistake the oracle;
to this sweet voice, could I enjoy the sight,
I should myself than style Queen of delight.
Pleasure shall be thy lackey; wilt thou hunt,
Then in an airy chariot drawn by birds,
On the winds downy back my love shall ride;
Mild Zephirus shall be thy waggoner;
Who if the heat offend, his 〈◊〉 wings
Shall fan cool air upon thee, yet my love,
If thou committest one sin, thou art not mine.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: Name it, and I'll avoid it for your sake.

lg.l: Thy mourning sisters shortly will return,
And seek thee on the rock from whence thou cam'st,
But shun their sight and speech; Psyche do this,
Thou robbest me else of love, thyself of bliss.
Not speak nor see my sisters; o what pleasure
Can Psyche take, locked in a golden jail?
Run not unto thy ruin gentle love;
Yet if thou needs wilt see and 〈◊〉 with them,
Command my 〈◊〉 Zephirus to bring them
From top of yonder rock into this veil;
But if they make inquiry who I am,
Fill both their laps with gold, and send them gone ▪
Besides I woo thee by this nuptial 〈◊〉,
Do not persuade me to disclose my shape,
Attempting that, thou losest this high state;
I then must leave thee, thou live desolate.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: In all these things, I will obey my love.

lg.l: Then Psyche, in thine unseen husband's hand
Clasp thy white fingers; I'll now 〈◊〉 thy bed
With the sweet spoils of thy lost maidenhead. Exeunt.
I like him best.
That Midas, is thy brother,
A piece of moving earth, illiterate, dull;
Who having in himself naught commendable,
Envies what's good in others; and yet dare
In his own impudence, with arts compare:
A block, a stone, yet learning he'll revile,
And a dull ignorant ass we will him style.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: But where's your poet ass among all these?

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.p: There's no such creature.

lg.l: Then what callest thou those
That let not men lie quiet in their graves,
But haunt their ghosts with ballatts, and bald rhymes?
Do they not teach the very fiends in hill
Speak in blank verse; do we not daily see
Every dull-witted ass spit poetry:
And for thy scene; thou bringest here on the stage
A young green-sickness baggage to run after
A little ape-faced boy thou term'st a god;
Is not this most absurd?
Misunderstanding fool, thus much conceive,
Psyche is anima, Psyche is the soul,
The soul a virgin, longs to be a bride,
The soul's immortal, whom then can she woo
But heaven? whom wed, but immortality:
O blame not Psyche then, if mad with rage,
She long for this so divine marriage.
But tell me then, why should Apollo say,
All love her, and yet none will marry her.
All love fair Psyche, all cast amorous eyes
On the soul's beauty, but who is't will wed her?
None with the foul will lead so strict a life
As heaven enjoins, with such a blessed wife.
Thou promp'st my understanding pretty well;
But why should Venus being Queen of love,
Wish her son Cupid to enamour her
On some base groom misshapen, and deformed?
By Venus here, is meant untemperate lust;
Lust woes her son desire, to inflame the soul
With some base groom, that's to some ugly sin;
Desire is good and ill; the evil swears
To obey his mother Venus, and vex Psyche:
But Cupid representing true desire,
Dotes on the souls sweet beauty, sends his servant
Zephirus; in whom, celestial pleasure's meant,
To entice his love, the soul, to his chaste bed,
Giving her heaven for her lost maidenhead.
Only one riddle more, and I have done;
Why did the poor girl Psyche take such pains?
What scrambling shift she made to climb the mountain,
And crawl through brakes and briers to get a husband.
This shows how many strong adversities,
Crosses, pricks, thorns, and stings of conscience,
Would throw the ambitious soul affecting heaven,
Into despair, and fainting diffidence,
Which Psyche must pass through; the soul must 〈◊〉
Through thousand lets, to 〈◊〉 eternity.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thou hast made this somewhat plain.

lg.l: Kind gentlemen,
long flaxen curled tresses crown his head.
Come, come, you shall not be enamoured
On my fair husband; this for all suffice,
He's young and rich.
O how my blood doth ri●
In envy of her high felicity; speak, what's his name?

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: Home, home; more music there, I must to rest:

lg.l: Ho Zephirus, come forth, and bring me brimful bags of gold:
Hold up your laps; tho'them you cannot see
That bring this gold, this largesse take from me;
Adieu, adieu: my duty to the King,
I needs must stop mine ears when Syrens sing.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Astioche.

lg.l: Petrea, o, I am mad to note her pride;
Her husband is no serpent as 'twas said,
And false Apollo sung; he is some god,
And this his temple, for no mortal hand
Hath laid these christiall pavements, clothed these meads
In never-fading liveries of green;
Flora you see clothes all the ground with flowers,
Flora is Psyche's handmaid; Zephirus
Is but her footboy, lackeys at her beck.
Yet she's our sister, and it doth me good
To see rich worth in any of our blood.
Thou art a fool Petrea, for I hate
That any's fortune should transcend my state;
She sends us hence in scorn, but we'll return,
And never cease, till by some treachery,
Her pride we make a slave to misery.
Patience great sir, you have not lost them all,
Doubtless the two last live.
Sir though they be your daughters, they're our wives,
And we are in no such despair of them.
Admit you were one for Astioche,
And that another for Petrea wept,
You two, but for two wives shed husbands tears;
For you and them, I sorrow all: your fears
Divided betwixt you; on me alone,
Lies like a mountain, and thus casteth down
Admetus wretched body, with his crown;
They followed Psyche and her 〈◊〉,
Hath given them death, us living misery.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.p: Rise royal sir, your daughters are returned.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: O where, which way; are my two daughters come?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.p: Yes sir, and both their laps are filled with gold.

lg.l: Wellcome to both in one; o can you tell
What fate your sister hath?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Psyche is well.

lg.l: So among mortals, it is often said,
Children and friends are well, when they are dead.
But Psyche lives, and on her breath attends.
Delights that far surmount all earthly joy;
Music, sweet voices, and ambrosian fare,
Winds, and the light-winged creatures of the air;
Clear channeled rivers, springs, and flowery meads,
Are proud when 〈◊〉 wantons on their streams,
When Psyche on their rich embroidery treads,
When Psyche guilds their crystal with her beams;
We have but seen our sister; and behold
She sends us with our laps full brimmed with gold.

sp.speaker: Adm.
sp.p: O, you amaze me daughters.

lg.l: Let joy banish amazement from your kingly thoughts
Psyche is wedded to some 〈◊〉,
And prays withal, our 〈◊〉 return again.
We grant it; we with you and these, will go
To Psyche's bower; desire inflames my mind,
To sit on the bright wings of that blessed wind.
O but the god that governs Psyche's thoughts;
For sure he is immortal; charged my sister
To talk with none but us.
Yet by the 〈◊〉 of our tongues we'll try
If we can win you so much liberty.
〈◊〉 my Astioche, but come again
To comfort him that must thy want complain;
Go with my love Petrea, but return
With winged speed, whilst 〈◊〉 your absence mourn;
Go with my blessing; blessed those sisters be,
That live like you in bonds of unity:
Give Psyche this; give her thou this Petrea,
Tell her she is myself, my soul's idea,
And say, whilst she is spotless, lovely white,Kisseth them.

and mad-folks ▪ grand 〈◊〉 of griefs, and groans; lord of lamentations, hero of his - 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 of 〈◊〉 and monsieur of mutton-laced.

sp.p: Here's a style I shall never be able to get over.

Nay, it 〈◊〉 my 〈◊〉 ▪

Just the same; by this trojan a 〈◊〉 〈◊〉, that one might stride over; on the other 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 a farmer, who had a light wench to his wife called Helen, that kept his sheep, whom Paris, one of 〈◊〉 mad lads, seeing and liking, ticeth over the brook, and lies with her in despite of her husband's teeth; for which wrong, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 for one 〈◊〉 his 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 was then high 〈◊〉 of the hundred, and complains to him: he sends to one Ulysses, a fair spoken fellow, and town-clerk, and to divers others, amongst whom was one 〈◊〉 fellow called Ajax, a butcher, who upon a holiday, brings a pair of 〈◊〉, and lays them down in the midst, where the
two hundreds were 〈◊〉 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 a 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 bold lad of the other side 〈◊〉, steps 〈◊〉, and takes them up; these two had a bout or two 〈◊〉 a broken pate; and here was all the circumstance of the Trojan wars.

sp.speaker: 1. Swa.
sp.p: To see what these poets can do.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: But listen to them, and they will fill your heads with a thousand 〈◊〉; observe one thing, there's none of you all sooner in 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 is troubled with their itch, for he will be in his amorets, and his canzonets, his pastorals, and his madrigals, to his Phillis, and his Amarillis.

sp.speaker: 1. Swa.
sp.p: O beauteous 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: And what's Amarillis thinkst thou?

sp.speaker: 1. Swa,
sp.p: A fair and lovely creature.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I'll show thee the contrary by her own name, amor is love, illis, is ill; is ill, cannot be good; ergo 〈◊〉 is stark naught; let one or two examples serve for more, there's one of our fairest nymphs called Susanna; what is Susanna, but Sus and 〈◊〉, which is 〈◊〉 plain Arcadia, Nan is a sow.

sp.speaker: 2. Swa.
sp.p: Well, you have taught us more than ever I understood before, concerning poetry.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p:
Come to me but one hour in a morning, and I'll read deeper philosophy to you; good-morrow neighbours; poets, quoth 'a; what's titule tu patule, but titles and pages; what's propria que maribus, but a proper man loves maribones, or feminno generi 〈◊〉, but the feminine gender is troublesome; what's Ovid, but quasi avoid; now should I be in love, with whom? with doll, what's that but
〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 black-pot, or what's 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 for 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 post: no Cupid ▪ 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 and all thy 〈◊〉.

lg.l: What's he that ●o 〈◊〉 our 〈◊〉?
And scorns that power which all the gods adore;
To whom Jove sometimes bends, and Neptune kneels,
Mars homageth, and Phoebus will submit,
Sly Mercury obey, and Vulcan bow too;
And all the rural gods and goddesses,
Tailors and nymphs, allow their sovereign;
He shall not scape unpunished.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: If I could but find one of these fantastical poets, or light upon that little god their patron, I would so tickle them.

lg.l: This Hobinall, this rustic, this base clown;
I find him of a dull and brainless eye,
Such as I know a golden-headed shaft
Will never enter; of a skin so thick,
As pointed silver hath no power to pierce:
For such gross fools, I have a boult in store,
Which though it cannot wound, shall give a blow,
To startle all within him.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O me, heigh-ho.

lg.l: Lie there base Midas bastard, that refuses
All-honoured love, and rail'st against the Muses.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
O coward, whatsoever thou art, to come behind a man
and strike him before, 〈◊〉 I saw nobody — to 〈◊〉 ▪ 〈◊〉 never give a man warning, o coward, I am paid, I am peppered; the case is altered, for any one may 〈◊〉 by the hugeness of the blow, that I 〈◊〉 in love; ay — me, that any wench were here, whose name is 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 I be in love with any madge, though she were an owlet, 〈◊〉 with any maid, though she looked like a malkin; o poetry, I find that I am poisoned with thee too; for methinks I could 〈◊〉 my prayers in blank-verse, nay let me see, I think I 〈◊〉 rhyme for a need;

lg.l: Cupid I 〈◊〉, since so I know thy 〈◊〉,
And I'll go 〈◊〉 me out so●e 〈◊〉 ▪
There's at this time a combat in my soul,
Whether to trust my well-known sister's better,
Or my yet unseen husband; I have asked,
Demanded, and inquired of all my 〈◊〉,
This fairy-train that hourly 〈◊〉 on me,
Yet none of them will tell me what he is ▪
Besides, this solitude to be alone,
Begins to grow most tedious, and my fears
Do every way distract me.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Why how now Psyche?

lg.l: O let mercies eyes
Shine on my fault.
Are these thy heaven-bounded vows?
Are all thy protestations guilded air?
Hast thou no more regard to my command,
Or thine own safety?

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: Dear love pardon me.

lg.l: Once more I do; and still must pardon thee,
And thou must still offend, still torture me;
Yet once again I'll try thy constancy:
Thy sisters are at hand.
But gentle love,
Shall I not speak to them?
Yes, but I woo thee
To send them quickly hence, or they'll undo thee;
They now are at the rock, bid the cool wind
To please thee, bring them to the place assigned.

div.stage: Enter Zephirus with the two sisters.

lg.l: Ho Zephirus,
Tell me the cause of your so quick return?
Psyche we come with danger of our lives,
To save our sister from ensuing harm.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: What harm? What danger?

lg.l: Danger eminent,
Once you refused our counsel, and denied
To let us know your husband, or his name.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Come, let's see him.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: O, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Escape the danger you are fallen in●.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: You cannot see him.

sp.speaker: Asti.
sp.p: Give us then his shape?

lg.l: His shape, why he's a man whose ●owiey head
Bows on his 〈◊〉, through the 〈◊〉 of age.
That cannot be; you 〈◊〉 he was a youth
Of comely stature, with long 〈◊〉 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: I am entrapped.

sp.speaker: Asti.
sp.p: Speak, did you ever see your husband?

lg.l: Why do you ask, pray trouble me no more;
Leave me, and I will fill your laps with gold.
Once thy gold tempted us to leave this 〈◊〉,
And to betray thy life to misery,
It shall not now; did not Apollo doom
Thy fatal marriage to some hideous beast;
How just is Phoebus in his auguries;
Last night, when we went 〈◊〉 laden with gold,
We spied a serpent gliding on the mead,
Who at the sight of us, writhing his head
Proudly into the air, first hissed at heaven,
Because it did not shade him from our eyes.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: How did that serpent vanish from your sight?

lg.l: In at these gates he rolled, Psyche be wise,
For though a while he dally with thy beauty,
Dulling thy taste with sweets, thy eyes with shows,
Thy ears with music, and sweet lullabies ▪
He will in time devour thee.
Miserable wretch,
How shall I fly the fate that follows me?
Whose help shall I invoke?
Tell us the truth,
And we'll devise some means to succour thee.
You are my sisters, I confess to you,
I never saw his 〈◊〉, know not his 〈◊〉 ▪
Eyes, hands, lips, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 touch,
That I have sworn, save his, there were none such,
Yet your strange story makes me to suspect
That he's some 〈◊〉, for he tells me still,
To see his glorious shape, will 〈◊〉 me ▪
Besides 〈◊〉 bids 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 your 〈◊〉,
Else you will breed my sorrow; this is that
Which troubles me.
Hear then my counsel; instantly provide
A keen-edged razor, and a 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 ▪
At night, when 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 on 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 eyes,
Steal from his speckled side, 〈◊〉 to 〈◊〉 light,
And without fear behold his horrid shape,
And with the razor cut his 〈◊〉 throat;
And so by death gain life, and he being dead,
Psyche shall 〈◊〉 some King be married.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: How doth our sister relish this device?

lg.l: I do embrace your council, and this night
I'll put the same in execution;
Come, you have made me resolute and bold,
And now receive your laps o'erswelled with gold.
Swell in thy pride, until thou breakest thy heart,
Yet come, we'll take her largesse ere we part.
Poet no more; I have enough of Psyche;
her sisters and the serpent, all of them
Most villainous 〈◊〉, I'll 〈◊〉 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉
To please myself, and keep 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉,
Thou'lt let me show thee 〈◊〉 of our 〈◊〉 sport,
Such as we use here in Arcadia,
I will endure no longer.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.p: Well, I am pleased.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I'll show thee in a 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.p: Art sometimes must give way to 〈◊〉.

div.stage: Enter Pan, clown, swains, and country-wenches; they dance, and exit.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Was not this sport indeed?

lg.l: My modesty gives thee no reprehension,
For I am well pleased with your pastoral mirth,
But as thou hadst a power over mine eyes,
To sit it out with patience; so lend me
Thy attentive ●ates.
〈◊〉 clear thy absurdities,
Nay, gross ones too; here Psyche lies abominably,
And says she has two husbands, the one young,
The other old: how 〈◊〉 thou answer this?
Though thy vain doubts be most familiar
To these judicious hearers, well experienced,
As well in matters moral as divine;
To thee I'll make it plain.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I prithee do.

lg.l: Did Psyche lie to say she had two loves?
How like art thou to Psyche, she to thee.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: To me, I scorn her likeness.

lg.l: In this point thou art,
For rather then thy sisters shall grow angry,
To make earth's drossy pleasures stay for thee,
Thou wilt exclaim with Psyche, Cupid's young;
The joys of heaven are all too young, too little
To be believed or looked at; if that fail,
Thou with the soul wil't say, my love is old,
Divine delights are crooked like old age,
Who will not vow, speak, nay swear any thing,
To have their vain delights served like a King.
'Tis pretty, but your echoes pleased me best;
O if a man had seen them.
With a mortal eye none can; in them is hid this mystery;
Celestial raptures, that to allure the sight,
Are seen no more than voices being on high,
Subject unto no weak, and fleshly eye.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: But why did Cupid hide himself from Psyche?

lg.l: O who dares pry into those mysteries,
That heaven would have concealed; for this she's charged
Not to see Cupid's face, to shun her sisters.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Those gadding girls, what did'st thou mean by them?

lg.l: The restless sins that travel night and day,
Envying her bliss, the sweet soul to betray.
Well, by this little I conceive the rest,
I care not greatly if I stay it out,
But if not liked, I'll either sleep or flout.
So will not these I hope, before they view
What horrid dangers Cupid's bride pursue.

div.head: Scene. i.
div.stage: Enter Psiche in night-attire, with a lamp and a raysor.

lg.l: Time's eldest daughter night, mother of 〈◊〉,
Thou gentle nurse, that with sweet lulabies,
Care-waking hearts to gentle slumber charmest;
Thou smooth-cheek negro night, the black-eyed Queen,
That ridest about the world on the soft backs
Of downy ravens sleek and sable plumes,
And from thy chariot, silent darkness ●lings;
In which man, beast, and bird, enveloped,
Takes their repose and rest; Psyche entreats thee,
No jar nor sound betray her bold attempt:Cup. discovered sleeping on a bed.
Soft silken veil that curtains in my doubt,
Give way to these white hands, these jealous eyes,
Sharp knife prepared for a red sacrifice;
Bright lamp conduct me to my love or hate,
Make me this night blessed, or infortunate:
Wondrous amazement! what do I behold?
A bow and quiver, these shafts tipped with gold,
With silver this; this sluggish arrow's head,
Is like my heavy heart, composed of lead;
such weapons 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 doth 〈◊〉 ▪
Psyche were happy if this Cupid were;
Malicious sisters, I your envy sec,
This is no serpent, but a deity:
What pretty loves, like silken slumbers lie,
Closing the covers of each crystal eye;
Hence thou prepared instrument of death,
Whilst Psyche sucks new life from his sweet breath:
Churl beauty, beauteous niggard, thus 〈◊〉,
Why didst thou from mine eyes this glory hide?
Ah me, thou envious light, what hast thou done?
Immortal powers, o succour Venus' son;
What hellish hag hath dropped this scalding oil
On love's celestial shape?

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: 'Twas Psyche's hand.

lg.l: How durst thou violate my dread command?
Venus my mother, bid me make thee dote
On some base groom; and I left her and heaven,
And with mine own darts wounded mine own breast;
For all these favours, wouldst thou murder me?

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: Let my weak sex plead for my great offence.

lg.l: No, for thy sake, this plague pursue thy sex;
You shall have appetites, and hot desires,
Which though supplied, shall ne'er be satisfied;
You shall be still rebellious, like the sea,
And like the winds inconstant; things forbid
You most shall covet, loathe what you should like;
You shall be wise in wishes, but enjoying,
Shall venture heaven's loss for a little toying:
Ho Zephirus.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: What will my dear love do?

lg.l: Hence, touch me not, I'll be no more thy love:
Discharge my servants from this fairy veil,
Resign thy office to the boisterous North,
Bid famine ride upon his frozen wings,
Till they be blasted with his poisonous breath;
Music, be turned to horror, smiles to tears,
Pleasures to shrieks, felicity to fears.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: Why do you plague the place for my offence?

lg.l: Why for thy sister's sake soughtest thou my hate?
But I will be revenged on them and thee,
On them, for thy sake, on thyself, for me.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: For pity hear poor Psyche.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: No, away?

lg.l: I have no way but yours; which way you fly,
I'll hang upon your wings, or fall, and die.
Cup. Soon shalt thou leave thy hold; run Zephirus,
Fetch Boreus — art thou come my Aquilon:
Boreus, I charge thee by Orithia's love,
Lay waste and barren this fair flowery grove,
And make this paradise a den of snakes;
For I will have it uglier than hell,
And none but ghastly screech-owls here shall dwell;
Breath winter's storms upon the blushing cheeks
Of beauteous Psyche; with thy boisterous breath,
Rend off her silks, and clothe her in torn rags;
hang on her loathed locks base deformity,
And bear her to her father, leave her there,
Barren of comfort, great with child of fear;
Psyche farewell, whilst thou with woes art crowned,
I must go gather helps to cure my wound.
With woes indeed; those wretches live in woe,
Whom love forsakes, and Psyche must do so.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Do you hear the news, you animals?

sp.speaker: 1. Swa.
sp.p: Is it worth the hearing?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: A question well asked, for it is musical news, and therefore worth your ears: Apollo being called by Venus from heaven, hath ever since kept Admetus his sheep, with whom Pan meeting, they fell in contention, whether his pipe or Apollo's harp could yield the better music, and which withal could sing the best; come then my sweet Amarillis, and take thy place amongst the rest, for this is the day of the trial, and amongst others, I heard my father Midas say, that all other business set a part, he would be at it; but there is one mischief late happened.

sp.speaker: 2. Swa.
sp.p: What's that I prithee?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Pan hath got a could, is hoarse, and hath lost his voice, and therefore hath chose me to sing in his place; and Phoebus, because he will take no advantage, hath picked out one of his pages to do the like for him; therefore come, make a lane, for by this time they are upon their entrance.

sp.speaker: 1. Swaine.
sp.p: But is it possible, that Pan's pipe dare contend with Apollo's harp?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Yes that it is possible, blind harper, and that my windpipe shall prove; make room, and get you all out of the lists save I, that am to be one of the combatants

div.stage: A flourish. Enter Apollo, Pan, Admetus, Petrea, Astioche, their two husbands, and Midas.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Who shall be judge?

sp.speaker: Apo.
sp.p: Admetus.

lg.l: Sacred Apollo, great pan pardon me;
It is a cunning much beyond my skill,
Therefore I humbly crave to be excused.
Admetus, for thy hospitality,
Phoebus will be thy friend, and gives thee leave
In this to use thy pleasure.
What thinks Phoebus
Of Midas, once of men, now King of beasts.

sp.speaker: Apol.
sp.p: No better man, so please him undertake it.

lg.l: Yes Phoebus, Midas will, and though poor Marsias,
For striving with thee had his skin pulled off,
Yet have we swains, and some too not far off,
I could have said, some near to me in blood,
Can tickle you for a tone.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Meaning me, and I will set out a throat.

sp.speaker: Apol.
sp.p: Is this thy champion?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Yes, and who's for thee?

lg.l: One of my minutes, hours, days, weeks, or months,
Or years, or seasons, that still wait on us,
and have done ever 〈◊〉 the first of time;
Not one can come amiss.

sp.speaker: Mr..
sp.p: Who shall begin?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: Most voices.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Apollo, Apollo.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: No matter though his champion begin, lot me alone to come up with the catastrophe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Silence, silence.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Phoebus unto thee 〈◊〉 sing,
O thou great 〈◊〉 King:
Thou the god of physic art,
Of poetry, and archery;
We sing unto thee with a heart,
Devoted to thy deity:
All bright glory cro● thy 〈◊〉,
Whose golden beams and rays are shed
As well upon the poor as rich ▪
For thou alike regardest each;
Phoebus unto thee we sing,
O thou great Idalian King.
I 〈◊〉, this was somewhat to th' purpose;
I needs must say 'twas pretty, but god Pa●,
now let us hear your champion?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Come stand forth?

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Thou that art called the bright Hiperion,
Were't thou more strong than Spanish Geryon,
That had three heads upon one man,
Compare not with our great god pan:
They call thee son of bright Latona,
But girt thee in thy torrid 〈◊〉,
Sweat, baste, and broil, as best thou can,
Thou art not like our dripping pan.
What cares he for the great god Neptune,
With all the breath that he is kept in;
Vulcan or Jove he scorns to bow to,
To Hermes, or the infernal Pluto.
Then thou that art the heavens bright eye,
Or burn, or scorch, or boil, or fry,
Be thou god, or be thou man,
Thou art not like our ●rying pan.
They call thee Phoebus, god of day,
Years months, weeks hours, of march and may;
Bring up thy 〈◊〉 in the 〈◊〉 ▪
We'll meet thee with our pudding pan.
Thyself in thy bright chariot settle,
With skillet armed, brasspot, or kettle,
With jugg, black-pot, with glass, or can,
No talking to our warming pan.
Thou hast thy beams, thy brows to deck,
Thou hast thy Daphne at thy beck;
Pan hath his horns, Syrinx, and Phillis,
And I Pan's swain, my Amarillis.
You Midas have heard both; these only wait
Your just and upright 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Is Phoebus pleased.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.p: Pleased.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And is pan content.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Now if my father can but censure as well as I sing, the town's ours.

lg.l: Yes son, I can, and that most learnedly:
Thy 〈◊〉 to Pan's pipe, yield god Phoebus,
For't is not now as in diebus
Illis, pan all the year we follow,
But semel in anno ridet Apollo,
Thy chorister cannot come 〈◊〉
The voice of this our chanticleer ▪
Then leave off these thy burning rays,
And give to pan the prick and praise,
Thy colour change, look pale and wan,
In honour of the great god pan.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A sentence, a sentence, a pan, a pan.

lg.l: Henceforth be all your ●urall music such,
Made out of tinkers, pans, and kettledrums;
And never henceforth may your fields be graced
With the sweet music of Apollo's lyre:
Midas for thee, may thy ears longer grow,
As shorter still thy judgement, dulness, and dotage,
Be only governed with those reverend hairs;
Let all like thee, that as they grow in time,
Decay in knowledge, have that old man's curse,
To be twice children: for thy squeaking son,
May all thy state thou leavest him at thy death,
Be to sing ballets through Arcadia,
And them to the like tunes; farewell Admetus,
My music lives unquestioned, what's amiss
Is not in us, but in their ignorance;
Thus undisparaged, Phoebus leaves the place,
And with them to succession, my disgrace.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: Phoebus is gone displeased.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Still may he be so.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Midas I'm sure has judged with equity.

div.stage: A storm. Enter Psiche and Boreas.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: But see father, see god pan, 〈◊〉 revenge, he hath not sent a blustering wind to blow us all hence; 'tis Boreas, 'tis Boreas.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Come Midas, come swains, till this storm be passed, let us away to shelter.

lg.l: Where art thou Psiche, how art thou deformed?
What air affords thee breath? what men be these?
Where shall I hid me; let no humane eye
which now attends thee?
Cupid, my dear lord,
Pardon my gilt, have pity on my sorrow?
I cannot, no I dare not, heaven, and earth,
The destinies, and all th' immortal powers,
Have with the iron pen of fate, writ down
Thy certain pain; did I not give thee charge,
To taste the pleasures of immortal love,
But not to wade too deep in mystery?
Could not my heavenly company suffice
To cheer the soul? but thou with earthly eyes
Must see my face; and view my real beauty,
Against my charge, thy love, and humane duty.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: I do entreat.

lg.l: Arise, kneel not to me;
But thank thy sisters, they apparelled thee
In that distractful shape; Psyche farewell,
I'll mourn in heaven, to see thy pains in hell.
Poor miserable child; in stead of tears,
My heart weeps blood; I am confounded quite:
I have three daughters, thou of all the rest,
Hadst in my true conceptions greatest share,
For which, I called thee Psyche, that's the soul,
For as my soul I loved thee; now I abjure
All interest in thy birth; 〈◊〉 from my court?
My hand shall ne'er lay blessing on thy head,
Nor my tongue grace thee with a daughter's name,
Thou art not mine, but the base birth of shame.
O whither shall a wretch convert her eyes,
when her own father shall her tears despise?
Attend Arcadians,
The proclamation of the Paphian Queen.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: When Hermes speaks, we are bound to all attendance.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: O yes, if any can bring Psyche unto Venus —

sp.speaker: Asti.
sp.p: Psyche whom you are sent to seek, stands there.

lg.l: Then here ends Mercury's commission:
Psyche, in Venus' name, I do arrest thee,
For wrongs to her and Cupid.
I obey
Your high arrest, and with an humble suit,
Prostrate myself to Catheria's wrath;
Where's angry Venus?
Frantic in this grove,
Mourning Adonis' death, — and here she coms.
Accursed bow, why didst thou not defend him?
He shall not die, Adonis still shall live;
Apollo, gentle Phoebus mount thy chariot,
And in his cold breast breathe celestial fire,
For all earth's simples cannot cure his wound;
Or if he must expire, command the muses
To give my love immortal memory:
Hast thou found Psyche? o that in this rage,
I could but now forget her.
See where she stands,
with downcast eyes, and weak upheaved hands.
Just of my height, my state, and proportion;
And were her pristine beauty lent her back,
Might in the rabble's judgement rival me:
Strumpet, profaner of our sacred rights,
How hast thou wronged me, and abused my son?
By aiming at my honour, and his life.
Dread Paphian Queen, for lovely Cupid's sake,
And this rich burden in my wretched womb,
Pity poor Psyche.
Hast thou played the strumpet,
And for thy sin's sake must I pardon thee?
No, that alone hath made me merciless.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: Help me dear father, sisters, Mercury.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: I dare not speak for thee.

sp.speaker: Asti.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: Poor Psyche, born unto adversity.

lg.l: Be not so bitter madam, for his sake,
By whom you are made a grandam.
I prove ● grandam to a strumpet's brat;
Go Mercury, and from some garner 〈◊〉
Five measures of five several sorts of grain;
Dispatch it Hermes.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What will Venus do?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Thou shalt know better when thou back returnest:

lg.l: You are young Venus, and the Queen of love,
That had th'ambition to be Cupid's wife,
And marry with a god; ho Boreus,
since Mercury is slack in his return,
Wind her enticing locks about thy arm,
And tossing her loose carcase in the air,
Fling it into the bosom of some storm,
And grind her bones to powder in the fall.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: Pity me Venus, father plead for me.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: 'Tis well done Hermes, hast thou brought the grain?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Madam I have.

lg.l: Then minion, here's your task,
Look on all these; see, thus I mingle them.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: And what must miserable Psyche do?

lg.l: To several heaves, with thine own hands divide
Each several seed ere the sun kiss the West,
Or look for death; go, and when that is done,
I'll ride to Paphos and enlarge my son,
Whom yet I keep close prisoner in my closet.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: Psyche adieu, none can reverse thy doom.

sp.speaker: Asti.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.p: Nor we.
sp.stage: Exit. all but mer. and Psi.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: I wish the earth my tomb.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Take patience Psyche, and be comforted.

lg.l: Comfort, alas what comfort can she find,
Whose father and dear friends prove so unkind.
For Cupid's sake, who for thy love, now 〈◊〉
A pair of golden shackles on his heels:
This Mercury will do, fly hence to Paphos,
and fetch him from his late imprisonment,
Then tell him of his mother's tyranny,
That done, we two will teach thee without pain,
In several heaps how to divide this grain.
And where have I been think'st thou Apuleius?
Didst thou not miss me?

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.p: Yes, I did not sleep, as thou didst in thy judgement.

lg.l: Then I perceive,
Thou knowest how I maintained our rural music,
Preferring it before Apollo's harp.
Yes, and by that infer, thou art all earthy,
Nothing celestial in thee.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: All's one for that; now for your moral.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.p: Wil't thou stay it out?

lg.l: No, 'tis too dull,
Unless thou'lt quicken me with some conceit,
Thy Psyche's sadness hath made me so heavy,
That Morpheus steals upon me.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.p: What wouldst thou see?

lg.l: Thy little Cupid I like pretty well,
And would see something else what he can do,
More than belongs to Psyche.
Well, to keep the awake,
I'll show thee now loves contrarieties,
Which was more than my promise.

div.stage: Enter a King and a beggar, a young man and an old woman, a lean man, a fat woman. Dance, and exit.

lg.l: I marry, this was somewhat like indeed;
Here's young and old; here's fat and lean; the beggar and the King;
Love hath power over all.
But to your moral now; why comes your Psyche
With a sharp razor, and a burning lamp,
To murder Cupid; than he wakes and chafes,
And flings house on't at windows, was't not so?
I'll tell thee; she charmed by her sister's tongues,
Thinks her fair love a serpent, and grown mad,
Would murder Cupid, tear even Jove from heaven;
Yet note the greatness of celestial mercy;
One glimpse, one lamp, one spark, one divine thought
Plucks back her ar●e, and more inflames her breast
With amorous raptures; but because poor soul,
She aimed to search forbidden mysteries,
Her eyes are blasted, Cupid loathes her sight,
He leaves her ugly, and his blessed bower
Is rent in pieces; for heaven seems to fall
When our poor souls turn diabolical.
For that 'twixt pan and Phoebus, I know best,
For I was there an umpire; but resolve me;
Why left he Psyche when she lost his love,
Yet mourned when she was left of all her friends.
All bid the wretched soul run to despair,
When leprous sin deforms her, but even then,
when the gods hate her? when she's scorned of men?
Cupid hangs in the air; his divine eyes
Shed tears for her, comforts her miseries.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yet he forsook her too.

lg.l: Till Psyche be made fair and angel-white,
She's not to stand in Cupid's glorious fight.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Well, I am answered.

lg.l: And for thy part Midas,
Laugh, sleep, or flout, nay snarl, and cavil too;
Which none of these here met I hope will do.

div.head: Scene. i.

lg.l: Within there, ho Pirackmon, when you knave?
Take in adonis quiver, and his bow,
And hang them up in Venus' armoury,
By Mars his gauntlet, and Achilles' sword:
Ha ha ha, I laugh until my sides be sore,
For joy that my wife's dandiprat is dead;
And my now Cyclops lay't on lustily;
There's half a hundred thunderbolts bespoke,
Which argues that the world is full of sin;
Neptune hath broke his mace, and Juno's coach
Must be new mended, and the hindmost wheels
Must have two spokes 〈◊〉 in; 〈◊〉 fore-horse
must have two new shoes, 〈◊〉, and one remove;
Pan's sheephook must be mended shortly too,
Ply it of all hands, we have much to do.
Master, here's one of Ceres' husbandmen
Would have a ploughshare, and a sith new ground.
New ground, new haltered, he shall stay his turn;
We shall deceive the gods and goddesses,
For a plough-jogging hind.

sp.speaker: 2. Ci.
sp.p: Here's Mercury to have his 〈◊〉 mended.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.p: He shall stay.

lg.l: Here 〈◊〉 Ganymede,
To have his master's hunting-nag new shod;
And Mars his lackey, with a broken gorget.

sp.speaker: 4. Ci,
sp.p: And here's a clown for hobnails.

lg.l: Here's the devil and all;
What would they have me do? I toil and moil
Worse than a mill-horse, scarce have slept a minute
This fortnight, and odd days; I have not time
To sit and eat, but I'll give over all,
And live upon my wife, as others do;
They say she hath good takings, ere I'll endure it,
I will do any thing; when I was made a smith,
Would I had been a bearward.

sp.speaker: 4. Ci.
sp.p: What shall we do first?

lg.l: Why first go hang yourselves:
I keep a dozen journeymen at least,
Besides my Cyclops and my prentices,
of all these evils had assaulted thee;
And till my mother's anger be appeased,
I dare do nothing; yet for our first love's sake,
Make me acquainted with thy second task,
And as I may be sure, I'll further it.
Let my lips kiss this earth whereon you tread,
In low submission; for her late injunction,
Transcends all humane possibility:
This viol I must fill at that springhead,
From whence Cocytus flows, that fearful stream,
Which feeds the river Styx.
Be advised by me,
Not far from Tenarus, whose barren top
Is crowned with clouds of smoke, there lies a mead,
O'ergrown with osiers, briars, and sycamores,
In this Jove's eagle (On whose dusky wings,
Ganymede flew to heaven) obscures himself
From jealous Juno's wrath ▪ inquire him out,
Tell him thy grief, and that thou cam'st from me,
From this hard task he will deliver thee.
Thanks glorious deity, upon my knees
Pressed down with this rich burden of thy love,
I beg that you will mediate 'twixt my errors,
And your stern mother's wrath.
Well get the gone,
'Tis I will front her indignation.
This way he ran with shackles on his heels,
and said he would to Vulcan: o but see
Where he stands cogging with him.
Now you runaway,
You disobedient, thou unhappy wag,
Where be the golden-fetters I left you bound in?
True, for my good behaviour, but you 〈◊〉
My bands are cancelled, and your son 〈◊〉 free.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: I'll whip you for't with 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 in wine.

lg.l: So you'll nettle 〈◊〉, and I must smart for't;
But when your own 〈◊〉 burn, and you desire
With him, or him, to glut your appetite,
Then gentle Cupid, then, my pretty son,
My love, my dear, my darling, and what not,
Till you have had your will.
With his 〈◊〉 〈◊〉,
He still prevents my anger: but for thee,
As crooked in thy manners as thy shape;
I thought, great fool, you durst not harbour him.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.p: No more I did, 〈◊〉 wife.

lg.l: Sweet mother Queen, buss my black 〈◊〉 for all that he hath done.
Was love to you, and kindness to your son.
Speak for me pan, as ere thou hopest to have
Thy broken hoke well mended.
When, canst tell?
I tell thee, I must first have besides that,
A dozen of branding-irons to mark my flock,
(The time draws near, sheepshearing is at hand)
Besides, two of my satyrs falling out
About a lamb, one of them burst his horn,
It must be tipped too; thou art well acquainted
with tipping horns.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.p: Ha, horns, with horns, how's that?

lg.l: Nay, ask your wife, I cannot speak of horns,
But still you take the last word to yourself,
For Venus makes, and Vulcan wears,
And Vulcan takes, and Venus bears.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.p: Vulcan wear horns?

lg.l: No sweetheart, you mistake,
Pan is the forked god, with horns was born,
And ever since, his tongue runs of the horn.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Speak shall I have my sheephook, and those irons?

lg.l: Yes pan, you shall,
But yet those horns have strucked deep to my heart.
Take heed they grow not upward to your head,
And tipping horns, your brows wear horns indeed:
But who comes here? Vulcan is this your wench?
T'hadst best look to him Venus.
Like your obedient servant, that lays down
Her life and labour at her mistress feet,
So comes poor Psyche, held between the arms
Of fear and duty; fear disheartening me,
Would pluck me back, but duty being more strong,
Bids me go forward, bending my weak knee
Before the shrine of sacred majesty;
Accept my service, who to gain your grace,
Would yield myself to ashy death's embrace.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Is this that water of th' infernal lake?

lg.l: This is that water, whose infections torrent
Runs from Cocitus, into Phlegeton,
Infernal Styx, and the black Acheron,
Dear goddess.
Art thou not a fawning counterfeit?
First I employed thee to divide my grain,
A task impossible for mortal hands,
This second as more hard, and yet 'tis done;
Thou workest by sorcery; but no damned spell
Shall keep me from my wrath, thy soul from hell.
Venus, sweet mouse, nay prithee do not chide,
Forgive, as I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Polt-foot, peace.

lg.l: Sweet mother, let your ire be mollified,
Since for her fault she hah endured this pain,
Banish all hate, and make her blessed again.
Again I charge thee not to speak for her:
Once more I'll try thee further, since thy heart
Is wedded to such hellish sorcery;
Hie to Proserpina, the black-browed Queen,
I'll send thee on my embassy to hell,
Tell her that sickness, with her ashy hand,
Hath swept away the beauty from my cheeks,
And I desire her send me some of hers;
Fetch me a box of beauty then from hell,
That's thy last labour, urge not a reply,
Do my command and live, refuse, and die.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: For my sake, my best mother, pity her.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: For thee I hate her, and for her hate thee.

lg.l: Nay gentle Venus, be more merciful,
for her great-belly's sake.
For that alone,
I'll hate you all, till she be fled and gone.
Then go I must, and going, ne'er return;
O Cupid, my inconstancy to thee,
Is cause of this my endless misery.
Withdraw thee Psyche till the rest be gone,
Anon I'll speak with thee.
Venus, Vulcan, Cupid, and god pan,
I summon you to appear at Ceres' plain,
To entertain the fair Proserpina,
For whom I now am sent, I must to hell
About Jove's embassy, Venus' farewell.
Hermes farewell, we'll meet at Ceres' plenteous court:
Come Cupid, follow me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Vulcan cannot go.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.p: Yes, but 'tis best to keep behind a shrew.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Then put her in before, on Venus, go.

lg.l: Psyche approach, but do not come too near,
That pride thou hast already bought too dear.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: O pity Psyche, she is sent to hell.

lg.l: It is the sound of hell wakes pities eye,
Else I had left thee to more misery;
my loves not done, though thou art quite undone,
Unless I arm thee 'gainst the darts of death,
Which hell aims at thee.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: Let thy sacred breath —

lg.l: Wound me no more with words, for they but grieve me ▪
Now mark what on thy journey must relieve thee:
First, high thee to the banks of Acheron,
Thou canst not miss the way, 'tis broad, and worn
With trampling of ten thousand passengers,
There shall thou find hell's churlish ferryman,
His name is Charon, there's to pay his hire,
Take heed thou lose it not, for doing so,
He'll beat, and leave thee on the shore of woe;
Being ferried over, thou shalt spy hell gates,
Thou needest not knock, they are open night and day,
Give Cerberus a sop, and pass away.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: And what's that Cerberus.

lg.l: Porter of hell,
Who must at thy return be bribed again;
My great desire to help thee, hinders thee,
I should have told thee when in Charon's barge,
Thou art wafting o'er the dreadful waves of Styx,
An aged man, with a pale countenance,
His name's oblivion, swimming in the flood,
Will heave his withered arms, and cry, help, help,
Save me from drowning; stretch not forth thy hand,
For if thou dost, thou ne'er returnest to shore,
Thou wil't forget my love, see me no more.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: I'll stop mine ears against oblivions cry.

lg.l: Being landed, thou shalt see old wrinkled hags,
spinning black threads, whilst folly reels them up;
He will let fall his reel, and pray they reach it,
But stoop not; they will likewise beckon thee
To sit down by them; but to spin a thread
Take heed, doing so, from me thou art banished.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: I'll shun their baltes.

lg.l: Being entered Pluto's court,
They all will 'tice thee with a thousand trains,
Shun all, and neither sit, nor eat with them,
Only deliver what thou art enjoined,
Receive the box of beauty and be gone,
Which still keep shut, let not thy daring eye
Behold the wealth that in the box doth lie.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: Dread Cupid —

lg.l: Now farewell, hadst thou but obeyed me,
Thy face had still been lovely, and mine eye
Doted on thee with heavenly jealousy.

sp.speaker: 1. Swa.
sp.p: And what dost thou think of Cupid now?

lg.l: Do not think I am so stupid,
But to think well of great god Cupid.

sp.speaker: 2. Swai.
sp.p: And what of poets.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: As poets, as of potentates, for since I played the last prize against Phoebus, in which I may say of myself, veni, vidi vici; I have been so troubled with a poetical itch, that I can scratch you out rhymes, and ballads, songs, and sonnets, odes, and madrigals, till they bleed again.

sp.speaker: 1. Swai.
sp.p: Then thou art reconciled to Homer.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Homer was honourable, Hesiod heroical, Virgil a vicegerent, Naso notorious, martial a Provost, Juvenal a jovial lad, and Persius a Paramount; what doc I think of poetry? of which myself am a professed member.

sp.speaker: 2. Swai.
sp.p: And may be very well spared, and yet the body never the worse, but thou mayest see what becomes of railing against Cupid, what a sweet mistress he hath put upon thee?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Who, my Amarillis.

sp.speaker: 1. Swai.
sp.p: Yes, the veriest dowdy in all Arcadia, even Mopsa compared with her, shows like a madam; first she's old —

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: It was very well said, to say first, because she was before us, and for being old, is not age reverend? and therefore in mine eyes she's honourable.

sp.speaker: 1. Swai.
sp.p: And wrinkled.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Is't not the fashion; do not our gentiles wear their hair crisped, the nymphs their gowns pleated, and the fawns their stockings, for the more grace, wrinkled; doth not the earth show well when 'tis ploughed, and the land best when it lies in furrows.

sp.speaker: 1. Swai.
sp.p: Besides, she hath a horrible long nose.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: That's to defend her lips, but thou sinner to sense, and renegade to reason, dost thou blame length in any thing? dost thou not wish thy life long, and knowest thou not that truth comes out at length; when all our joys are gone and passed, doth not long looked for, come at last; if any of our nymphs be wronged, will she not say, 'tis long of me, 'tis long of thee, or long of him; if they buy any commodity by the yard, do they not wish it long; your advocate wishes to have a law suit hang long; and the poor client, be his cloak never so short, and threadbare, yet would be glad to wear it longer.

lg.l: No married man, but doth his wife much wrong,
though he himself be short, to have nothing long.

sp.speaker: 2. Swa.
sp.p: The short and the long o't is, she's an ugly creature, make of her what thou canst.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Make of her what I can; o that all, or any of you could like me, look upon her with the eyes of poetry, I would then let you know what I have made of her.

sp.speaker: 1. Swa.
sp.p: Prithee let's hear't.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Then listen hither, o you imps of ignorance;

lg.l: O tell me, have you ever seen,
Since you were born unto this day,
Which is long since, a wit so green,
And covered with a head so grey.
To praise her still, my muses will is,
Although therein I have no cunning,
Yet is the nose of Amarillis
Like to a cock, long, and still running.
Her eyes, though dim, to seem clear,
And they of rheum can well dispose,
The one doth blink, the other blear,
In pearl-drops striving with her nose.
Her breast are like two beds of bliss,
Or rather like two lean-cows udders,
Which shows that she no change ling is,
Because they say, such were her mothers.
Those few teeth left her in her head,
Now stand like hedge-stakes in her gums,
Full of white dandruff is her head,
She puts the cobbler down for thumbs.
Her sides be long, her belly lank,
And of her legs what should I say,
But that she feels well in the stank,
And both her feet, themselves display.

sp.speaker: 1. Swai.
sp.p: All the Homers in Asia could never have come so near the business.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: From head to foot, for her stature and years, pattern her in all Arcadia; say she be a foul beast in your eyes, yet she is my hyren; and showing foul to others, and fair to me, I shall live the happier, and she the honester, but I have a remedy against all this in spite of Cupid.

sp.speaker: 2. Swai.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I hear Psyche his mistress, is sent to hell for a box of beauty, 'tis but waylay of her, and taking it from her, than Amarillis shall compare with any other she that dare.

lg.l: This last I liked, and had it all been such,
Only a mere discourse 'twixt swains and clowns,
It then had pleased me; now some quaint device,
Some kickshaw or other to keep me waking.
Then by the leave of these spectators here,
I'll suit me to thy low capacity;
letting him know, this day Latona's son
Enters the first house of his zodiac,
And with his guilt beams welcomes in the spring;
This day the virgins of Sicilia,
Old wives, young children, soldiers, citizens,
Princes and prelates, on Cissephus' banks,
Are gathered in well-ordered multitudes,
Dancing in choruses, singing mirthful lays,
Such as Jambe, Megamira's maid,
Sung, when she mourned her daughter's ravishment:
This day hath Ceres called a session's,
Where Proserpine must be; but ere she leave
The black imperial throne of this low world,
Pische the daughter to th' Arcadian King,
Must do a message to her deity.
We know th' intent of that great influence,
With all the purpose of the Paphian Queen,
She means proud Psyche never shall return,
And we will keep her; Charon fetch her o'er.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: She's come already.

sp.speaker: Mino.
sp.p: Then conduct her in.

lg.l: Hell's full enough of shrews; if she be fair,
I know she's cursed, pray let her tarry there,
A cursed quean's tongue, the very fiends still fear.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Fetch her I say, Venus shall be revenged.

sp.speaker: Eac.
sp.p: Go Charon, wait upon him Cerberus.

lg.l: If she perform the customs of our court,
Being sent on message from supernal powers,
We can then with no justice keep her here.
True Minos, 'tis the law of hell and fate;
yet Cerberus and Charon, get you gone,
Tell Psyche that hell's King, and Proserpine,
With Minos benched, Aeacus and Radamanth,
Upon their black tribunals, sends for her;
You furies with your envious eyes attend,
Lest Psyche 'gainst our customs shall offend.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Come Cerberus, come hags, fetch Psyche in.

lg.l: Yes, and for all her stains, and leprosy,
Methinks I now could eat her.
Psyche is well instructed Rhadamant,
Her husband Cupid gave her certain rules,
For her uncertain journey.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Here she comes.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.p: My sop, hast thou thy naulum ferryman?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Psyche stand forth, nay poor soul, tremble not.

lg.l: How came this woman over Acheron?
Reached she not hand to help oblivion?
No, yet the wretch made many a piteous cry,
Yet she looked on him with a scornful eye.
How did she pass the hags, that spun the 〈◊〉
Of idle-folly, in the path of hell?
They all desired her help, but she denied
To set a finger unto folly's thread.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: She hath done well, why kneelest thou on the ground?

lg.l: I kneel to Proserpine, for I am sent
By sacred Venus for a box of beauty.
At her return from hell it should be done.
Here Hermes, take my Queen Proserpina,
Return her when the sister of the sun
Hath six times compassed her silver sphere;
Commend me to my mother, great Jove's wife,
My sister Pallas, and to all the gods,
So farewell Pluto's joy, all hell shall mourn
With hideous cries, till my fair love return.
Many a long look have my watchful eyes
Sent out to meet with Psyche, here she comes,Enter Psyche.
And in her hand the box, Cupid stand close,
And overhear the sum of her discourse.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: This is she, I know her by her martyred face; Venus did well to send her for beauty, for poor soul, she hath need on't, I have dogged her, to see if I could find her at any advantage, to steal away her box; I have already got love from Cupid; I have got poetry from Apollo, and if I could now get beauty from Psyche, Phaon the fair ferryman, was never so famous in Sicilia, as I Coridon shall be in Arcadia.

lg.l: You traitorous thoughts, no more assault me thus,
My lovely Cupid charged me not to see
What Proserpine sent Venus in this box,
The like command did hell's Queen lie on me,
O heaven, yet I shall die except I do't.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I Psyche, what still in your longing 〈◊〉?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: That's it, nay I shall know't, if I 〈◊〉 't again.

lg.l: It's beauty Psyche, and 〈◊〉,
And thou art ugly, this will make thee shine,
And change this earthy form to shape divine;
Open it boldly, but I shall offend,
Why say I do, 'tis but the breach of 〈◊〉,
And who'll not venture to get heavenly beauty,
Rich beauty, ever fresh, never decaying,
Which lies entombed in this heavenly shrine;
Nor in this bold attempt think me profane,
Striving thus spotted, to be free from 〈◊〉.
Nay I thought I should take you napping,
And thou shalt go with me; for 'tis my duty,Takes up the box.
My mistress being a blowse, to find her beauty.

sp.speaker: Cup.

lg.l: To make thee lovely in thy mistress eyes,
Make use of that, and boast of thy rich prize.

sp.stage: Cupid lays a counterfeit 〈◊〉 by him.

lg.l: But foolish girl; alas why blame I thee,
When all thy sex is guilty of like pride,
And ever was? but where's this beauty now?
Turned into slumbers, and like watery pearls
Of honey-tasting dew hangs on 〈◊〉 lids:
She wakes again; I have swept off the slumber
That hung so heavy on 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉,
Which 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 in, the 〈◊〉 of all true 〈◊〉 ▪

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: Where am I now? Dread Cupid 〈◊〉 me.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Come rise, and wipe away these fruitless tears;

sp.speaker: 2. Swai.
sp.p: Like thee, I'd rather see thee hanged; dost thou think we mean to wear vizors.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: This 'tis to be 〈◊〉 mortals, and have no addition of learning or travel; their dull eyes cannot judge of celestial beauty: but where's my 〈◊〉, and the god of marriage Hymen?

sp.speaker: 1. Swai.
sp.p: They both stay for thee in Venus' temple; but I hope thou wilt not be married to her in this pickle?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Will I not, yes, and dazzle all their eyes that shall look on me, especially my 〈◊〉, and she must needs have some part of my theft, all is not gone, something for her is left:

lg.l: Lead on, lead on, this day you shall be my men,
And thus in pomp will we go meet with Hymen:
And Dicken, if anon thou wilt be sinful
To drink with me, I will give thee thy skinful:
If any here, I speak it out of duty,
〈◊〉 complexion from my box of beauty,
This might I am busy, let him come tomorrow,
They shall have store, if they will buy, or borrow.

div.stage: Enter Phoebus, Pan, Vulcan, Venus, Admetus, Astioche, Petrea, Menetius, and Zelotes.

lg.l: By this I know, that Minks is come from hell,
And here she harbours; but Arcadian King ▪
Deliver 〈◊〉, or by our dreadful frown,
I'll spoil thy courts, and cast thy temples down;
〈◊〉 her longer, not the god's 〈◊〉
Shall guard her from the death, my rage intends.
Dread Queen of 〈◊〉, she remains not here,
nor think that I abet her, though my child,
Against your wrath, or power; nay, did she sojourn
In any place where I have free command,
I'd cause her to be fetch't thence instantly,
And as your slave and vassal tender her.
If she be safe returned from 〈◊〉,
She must be pardoned, and become divine,
But to conceal her being, and keep back
Her present sight, aims at her future wrack.
If ever in fair Venus I had power,
Or graced her summer 〈◊〉 with my 〈◊〉,
At length with a commisserating eye,
Look on distressed Psyche.
Do good wife,
Use her with all the favour thou canst think,
Connive at her, as I at thy faults wink.
And pan protests by 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 brown 〈◊〉
The fairest nymph, since 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉
Be friends with her, my 〈◊〉 all shall play,
And I with them make this a holiday.
To all these gods, to Venus, and this 〈◊〉,
Health from the son of Saturn, and Queen Ceres.
Welcome, what would the messenger of love
To us, or these?
Pan, Vulcan, and yourself,
With Phoebus, and the great Arcadian King,
must be this day at Ceres' sowing-feast,
Unto which annual meeting, see fair Proserpine
Is come from Pluto's court.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Welcome fair Queen.

lg.l: Welcome fair sister, from the vaults below,
We two are twins, of 〈◊〉 Latona born,
And were together 〈◊〉 in 〈◊〉 I'll;
You guide the night, as I direct the day,
Darkness and light, betwixt us we divide,
Nor square, but in our mutual orbs agree,
Unless you move just 'twixt the earth and me,
For then you eclipse my lustre.
Cousin Queen,
I am even moonsick, and half merry mad,
For joy of thy arrival.
By our crests
We should be cousins, for we both are horned,
And 〈◊〉 of our ki● too; but sweet goddess,
Now I bethink me of th' Arcadian nymphs,
I am bound to thee for many a pretty sight,
And much good sport I have had by thy moonlight.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: To give you meeting, I am come from hell.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Saw you not Psyche there?

lg.l: Love's Queen I did,
Hither she comes with Cupid, hand in hand,
Her leprosy, through labour, is made clear,
And beauteous in your eye, she'll now appear,
Celestial seaborn Queen, I here present you
my Psyche, who hath satisfied your will:
Deliver her, fair love, from Proserpine,
The box of beauty, endless, and divine.
Guided by love, lord of my life and hope,
I come undaunted to your gracious sight,
Hoping my sufferance hath outworn his wrath?
She hath scaped hell, and now the task is done,
And I still crossed by a disobedient son;
But tell me how this leoper came thus fair?
At my entreat it was,
Amongst all the gods I claimed her for my wife,
Who taking a joint pity of her wrongs,
Gave their consent, and then great love himself
Called for a cup of immortality,
Drank part to her, and Psyche quaffed the rest,
At which, deformity forsook her quite,
And she made fair, and then proclaimed my bride,
Jove vowing, she● should now be 〈◊〉.
I see I cannot conquer destiny,
By fate she first was thine, I give her thee.
Now Psyche, you must see your sisters judged,
Unstaid Petrea, and unkind 〈◊〉,
Admetus, you must be their sentencer.

sp.speaker: Asti.
sp.p: Husband, your knees.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: My dear lord plead for us.

sp.speaker: Asti.
sp.p: Wil● neither; yet father.

lg.l: Wretch's peace,
Psyche by you was torn from her delight,
And rudely rent from Cupid's paradise;
'Twas you that robbed her of a father's love;
by your alurements she was sent to hell,
And had not divine aid 〈◊〉 her thence,
Poor soul for ever sh' had ●in there detained,
For which, to endless durance I adjudge you;
For merit's silver gates are always barred
To hearts impenitent, and wilful hard.
Have pity on them father, gentle husband,
Remember not their fraud in tempting me:
You gods, and goddesses, with Psyche join
To beg their pardons, all you Arcadians kneel;
For had they not my happiness envied,
My love and patience had not so been tried.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We all will mediate for them.

lg.l: Then daughters, give your sister Psyche thanks,
And to her virtues be a 〈◊〉 still,
As having made atonement for your ill.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We'll henceforth be her handmaids.

lg.l: They shall attend her unto plenty's bower,
Where Ceres, Queen of all fertility,
Invites us with the other gods to feast.
There Jove and 〈◊〉 shall lead Cupid's Queen,
To the bright palace of eternity;
Bacchus shall give us wine, and Ganymede
Shall crown our full cups with the grapes pure blood;
Ceres shall yield us all earth's delicates,
The graces shall bring balm ▪ the muses sing
In Cupid's honour, loves immortal King.
Vulcan will dance, and sing, and skip, and 〈◊〉,
And with his smoky jests make 〈◊〉 laugh.
Such as love me, make me their precedent,
see, thus I take fair Psyche by the hand,
Mercury do you the like to Proserpine,
My mother Venus cannot want a mate;
In honour of our marriage, match yourselves,
And with a measure grace our nuptials,
But such as do not love to be in motion,
View as 〈◊〉, how our joy appears,
Dancing to the sweet music ●e of the spheres.

div.stage: A dance of Cupid, Psiche, the gods and goddesses.

lg.l: Now circle Psyche in a fairy ring,
Whilst I and Venus grace her with this crown;
This done, to feast with Ceres, and the gods
And next unto the palace of the sun,
To end those sacred writes we have begun.
Is this your moral? This your poetry?
What hast thou done, what spoke, what represented,
Which I with all these cannot justly tax?
Yes, all like thee th' obtuse and stupid minds,
But there's an understanding that hath depth
Beyond thy shallow nonsense; there's a wit,
A brain which thou wantest, I to that submit.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And ever in that thou foolest thyself.

lg.l: Nay then,
I by the favour of these gentlemen,
Will arbitrate this strife; one seeks to advance
his art, the other stands for ignorance;
Both hope, and both shall have their merits full,
Here's meed for either, both the apt, and dull,
Pleased or displeased, this censure I allow;
Keep thou the ass's ears ▪ the laurel thou:
If you, judicious, this my doom commend,
Psyche by you shall doubly crowned ascend;
And than this legacy I leave behind,
Where ere you love, prove of one faith, one mind.
The spring comes on, and Cupid doth divine,
Each shall enjoy his best loved Valentine,
Which when you have, may you like us agree,
And at your best retirements think on me.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
